author: cian riordan
content: Agreed -- be critical of everything. Be critical of things that are expensive for the sake of being expensive. Things that are just  instagram ads shilling to newbies. Critical of  Greg Wells pandering to whatever his base is. But recommending a 4k converter based on 'audible conversion quality' isn't helpful if the consumer doesn't have a million other ducks in a row first -- room treatment, adequate monitoring, proper gainstaging, etc. Jon has that figured out, so it makes sense for him. But when people come into a forum with questionable knowledge and background in music production asking what's the best converter, I think it's fair to ask some prying questions before just making blanket recommendations on what one person heard or not. I have plenty of semi-OK stuff that still gets used on the regular, and plenty of expensive gear that I would happily toss out of my workflow. They're all just tools. And whether its bougie DW Fearn or a black-friday Acustica plugin, , if it works for your workflow and gets you results you're happy with, then its worth whatever money you're willing to pay for it.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
i love this question. i've been doing this for long enough that the cycles of how records sound has changed several times. so every few years i try and take some time to unlearn/relearn.

there's no good short answer, but i'd start with taking some time outside of mixing to just listen to records. whether you've done this before or not, get to know your speakers and your monitoring environment better than before. listen to your favorite records that you know well, and make some tweaks. you don't necessarily have to redo your whole setup, but listen to your speakers in slightly different positions, different settings on the back of the speaker, etc. and really dig into listening and enjoy yourself.

that's usually enough to make me think about mixes very differently (which ultimately means i get better when i re-incorporate most of the things i already know). but if you need more, just try and simplify. start a mixing by just leveling everything. clip gain and leveling and panning. then balance frequencies and compress (via compressor or saturator or limiter or whatever). basically, with fresh ears, go back to basics.

not sure if that will transform you into a new mixer, but that's an outline of an approach i use when i feel like i need a big talent upgrade

author: cian riordan
content:
3) Not all manufacturers are created equal. With vinyl pressing plants months behind on their bookings, there are many budget plants that seem to be doing things for cheaper and quicker. You get what you pay for. QRP in Kansas are the best in the business. RTI in CA used to be the gold standard, but they dogged me real hard on a project about 10 years ago and never made things right. Even Doug Sax had to step in to set them straight.

The short of it is, if someone is venturing down the path of manufacturing vinyl for their project — *especially* if it’s self funded — they have to ask what they’re really looking to achieve. If they want a high-quality, analog preservation of their record for all to enjoy, then they need to be prepared to spend some real coin to achieve good results. If they just want a physical item to sell at shows and toss in a download code — that’s OK too — but it will still be pricey, and probably won’t sound great if you do it on the cheap. Just my $0.02.

author: Slow Hand
content:
If your position as a studio runner is paying dividends and you can sustain the lifestyle and afford to go without compensation then continue down that path. It sounds like you're in a position where people may not be giving you the time of day. At this point what a potential mentor figure will be seeking from you is an assurance that you are committed to the path and that their effort will not be wasted on someone who is not committed. 

Considering your position, right now I would recommend adopting an attitude of A) respectful persistence when asking others for insight and help B) private study and a self-starting attitude to make things happen for yourself without their assistance C) actively seeking opportunities to assist, contribute, and be of help to others and D) building your own network of creative collaborators with whom you can continue to create and experiment together.

author: cy (sigh)
content:
it varies greatly with the artist /genre id say. some artist i write/produce for and they come with no musical ideas besides their likes and dislikes. some are more involved and will have ideas that'll you'll be tasked to bring to reality. 

i highly recommend having at least a handful of things to present from jump. these can be some progressions or a couple lead melodies and a few drums. doesn't have to be complete but in most cases its better if it has direction on its own. if at all possible i would have the artist send you sonic references to what they've been feeling recently and maybe some spiritual /energy reference as to the type of performances they might be interested in doing themselves.

I've asked folks to make a ahort Playlist and based on that I'll add a few more songs and we'll listen to those while discussing /shooting the shit for a few minutes before starting. 

if they have a concept or idea in mind well work from there. if they're coming in blank then id usually touch on some of the prepped stuff and start playing around with old/new parts to find something we groove with. 

on the other end or the spectrum there are artists im familiar enough with that they'll just ask me to play anything i have that's not used or they'll hit me up and just ask to send stuff. 

the back and forth ones are usually more involved in production and some of them will do the same in the room or not. i.e tell you to take stuff out /out stuff in and others will do it themselves. especially if they play instruments. 
how much you chop /edit their parts will also depend on the relationship but i always let them know that im gonna always experiment and we can always take a step back if i go too far. 
how you send the files will depend on your trust.

i rarely do random pitches anymore unless i know the person or their primary producer is asking for starters. 

you'll likely have to adjust a lot at first if you haven't worked w them much but you learn your clients w time

author: Slow Hand
content:
Hey. Welcome! 

Based on what you've shared, it sounds like you're early in your journey making records. There are a lot of reasons that an Apollo might be a good investment, but buying them for the converters probably isn't the best use of your money at this stage.

The difference that converters will make (if any) is very very small compared to other factors. Factors like having a good room to listen in, acoustic treatment for the room, and the monitors you're listening through. I would prioritize those and consider converters to be very low priority until you get those other factors working well.

So unless there are other reasons that you'd like to have an Apollo I think you can save your money for the time being.

author: LAPhill
content:
Are you looking for resources on writing/production, or mixing? Just like with the record side, there's so much noise from bedroom composers and people that have zero real-world experience. And as Ruairi is always saying, even the people with real success often can't teach what they know. Maybe I'm a bit cranky after an 8 hour delay at the airport yesterday, but Spitfire has gotten quite good at creating "tutorial" videos that are thinly veiled advertisements, and many of their libraries are the equivalent of one-knob plugins or CLA vocals. Selling paint-by-numbers solutions to naïve kids who want to get into scoring (They're far from the only ones guilty of this). But to focus on some of the channels I think are actually worth their salt:

8-Bit Music Theory: https://www.youtube.com/@8bitMusicTheory/videos
Can be a bit basic at times, but he talks a lot about structure which, IMO, is becoming a lost art in modern scoring.

Anne-Kathrin Dern: https://youtube.com/playlist?list=PLWJg1w7F3PKPbSpEF2YOejVjWAg-KcM3Z
Not the biggest name out there, but she has a no-bullshit way of explaining things about orchestration and theory that is clear and concise. As far as "teachers," I think she's a good one.

Alan Meyerson Waves Sessions: https://youtu.be/h9jZqn5lnw4
I hesitate to include this. I know for a fact that Alan swapped out a bunch of his go-to plugins to make everything a Waves product. I haven't watched this in awhile, but it's a good insight into how he sets up a big mix session and why he makes some of his decisions. He's also playing to the camera/audience some, so this is a your-mileage-may-vary recommendation.

McGowen Soundworks: https://www.youtube.com/@McGowanSoundworks/featured
Phil knows his shit, and goes pretty deep breaking down a few actual mixes, which is pretty rare to find.

If I think of others, I'll report back. Hope that helps

If you have a DI box, an outboard preamp you want to use, and an available line input on your interface yes.

author: Rollmottle
content:
Just taking the time to figure out the right changeover strategy and timing so that I could actually make the move once I basically had two fully functioning rigs stood up in parallel. My additional complicating factor is having a laptop that is a dupe of the studio rig, so keeping it all straight and everything in sync is a bit of a puzzle. 

I took the transition as the opportunity to phase out some mechanical drives so I had to get some new drives for the M4 instead of re-using the old Time Machine mechanical drive. The M4 mini only has Thunderbolt/USB C ports -- the M1 has USB A's and Thunderbolt/USB C's so I needed a TB hub to get my old USB hub to play on the M4. The move forced me to sort out my iLok strategy between my mastering rig and my production rig because it was quite messy (I ended up getting a 2nd iLok for the M4 to make things way easier between it and the laptop). It was just a lot of little stuff for me. If you're not changing machine form factors and it's mostly a software exercise, then it might be worth it.

author: Zack Hames
content:
Alright gang - i've got this Otari MX5050 up and running and I wanted to ask if anyone had recommendations for buying new 1/4" tape reels to record with in 2025/26.

Research I've done seems spotty, some people saying they've bought new tapes that were already shedding/sticky, etc. just wanted to see if anyone had current info or advice.


SIde question; apparently after some time, tape reels simply go bad and have to be baked more or less every time you want to use them. So for those who have been using tape for a long while or did back in the day, you can't just use any old reel after baking it for a project? or can you say, bake it, use it for the project (record 2 track mix to tape, etc) and then just store it and re-bake it and use it again for the next project? 

I didn't grow up with tape but I love the sound and find the whole process romantic, despite how much extra work calibrating tape machines and maintaining them and the unpredictable nature of tape.

author: Rollmottle
content: The point of the test pressing isn't to pick one, it's more of a sanity check on the vinyl master.  I would always recommend an acetate to avoid the pain in the ass of discovering a problem with your master at test pressing. The acetate precedes the sign off on the master and allows you to hear what your music MIGHT sound like on a record. It is definitely lesser quality than a test pressing and a full vinyl run, but the $80 or $100 it costs will be money well spent to avoid a wasted cycle and cost of a bunk test-pressing.

author: peterlabberton
content: I’m sure you’ve read this or could find it with a quick google search, but starting with the first reflection points would be my first step. Side walls next to the listening position and ceiling above. Then probably behind the listening position and perhaps behind the speakers. If you have anything to use as a bass trap, I’d recommend using something like fuzzmeasure to shoot the room and experiment with placing that stuff in different places. You’ll be able to see peaks and valleys moving around in the low end, assuming what you’re using is actually effective at sucking up bass. There are people with much more knowledge than me, but that’s where I’d start!

author: Rollmottle
content: the concept is to couple your speakers to the front wall to remove or minimize SBIR and to leverage the room gain you get by being up against the boundary and then treat that energy at the rear wall. you will see most folks recommend this approach in small room contexts. i forget what exactly is considered an acoustically small room but most all residential rooms fall into this bucket.

author: Rob Domos
content:
If it’s the hissing kind of noise that you get more of when you switch from condensers to dynamics and ribbons, then it’s not the kind of noise that is coming from the room. 

In rooms the main things you would be concerned about would be reflection (which you fix with treatment) and mechanical noise from things like computer fans, clocks, etc. and condenser mics would pick those kinds of sounds up more, not less. 

Any unison pre in the Apollo should be plenty low noise to not bother you on your condenser mics. I agree with others that not using any unison pre will make the noise floor lower, but I disagree with them in that I think using the unison pres is a pretty good idea often. 

That said, if you’re struggling with noise, definitely try not compressing on the way in because compressors are only going to raise the noise floor. 

On dynamic mics and ribbon mics, you can decrease your noise floor pretty considerably by picking up a cloudlifter and throwing that in the chain. 

If you do all of the above and still have a high noise floor then either the Apollo is broken (which is pretty unlikely), or your microphone is picking up mechanical noise from your air conditioning, computer fan, refrigerator, etc. if those are the issue, then tackle the issue there. Turn off the A/C, turn off the fridge, turn off the LED lights, etc and see what you hear.

author: chadwahlbrink
content:
I use a smart plug to turn on and off my noisy raid archive drives each night via a Furman power conditioner. They mount when the plug turns on, then Keyboard maestro ejects them a few hours later, and they turn off with HomeKit automation. I was tired of coming down to work and having the drives humming super loud when I walk in. 

I want to get another plug for my other Furman that powers my Apollo and monitors. I do turn off the Furman switch instead of individual components. 

All that to say, you should be good to use a smart switch for something like this. I have the WeMo plug currently. The only caution is that it’s often “good practice” to turn off your monitors before anything else, although modern gear seems a bit better about not popping your monitors!

author: ! Andy !
content:
Hi Ya'll! I'm just having osme routing issues with the evo 8 sending/returning through a mic pre. I'm not super familiar with the evo, so anyone w/ experience with it i'd appreciate the input. Here's my setup. I'm sending from output 3 on the evo 8, via a xlr cable (w/ trs adaptor attached at the audient output side), into the input of a WA273.

I am then coming out of the 273 into input 4 of the Evo 8. Using abletons external audio effect device & always am getting signal on output 3, but never any back on input 4. I know that the units are communicating, as if I crank all the input gain up on evo 8, & output on 273, it affects the white noise being sent through both.

I've tried all different cables etc to make sure it's working, but it's always the same each time. Any thoughts? It could also be a evo 8 mixer thing which i'm inspecting now, still haven't gotten used to the software.

Apologies if the message is a little convoluted, my brain is being melted by this. Appreciate all input! 🙂

author: Adam Thein
content:
I’d take a look at the interface software - are the outputs to 3+4 turned up in the audient software?  Are you getting visual feedback of signal hitting those channels outside Ableton?

I’d remove as many variables as possible and test each part of the chain individually.  Try connecting the output of the Evo 8 ch 3 back into the Evo 8 input 4 without the 273 first and make sure it isn’t a software issue, then check the analog connections one at a time if that works.  My guess is a software thing with the Audient mixer.

Exactly.

author: Adam Thein
content:
I'd get in touch with a music lawyer who can help you make sure you have everything in place to collect all your back end - there's a lot of revenue sources you'll want to make sure you are collecting from.

Often you'll have had a producer agreement in place and a letter of direction that will be sent to the distributor/label so that if you have points on the master you'll be paid directly from them.

You'll also need to have a PRO/Publisher in place to collect songwriting royalties, and many folks have in place a publisher deal or publisher admin deal to collect those royalties on your behalf in exhange for a % of your royalty.  In my case I am set up with BMI in the US as my PRO and Publisher and have an admin pub deal with Sentric to collect in territories outside the US.

Also you'll want to be set up with SoundExchange to collect digital performance royalties (SiriusXM, iHeart, Pandora).  This often also involves the letter of direction that is kicked off with your producer agreement.

I'm probably forgetting something but I'd highly recommend talking with a music lawyer to get things set up and working for you.

author: noahc

author: Zack Hames
content:
Prophet 6 is like the be all end all for hardware synths. If I could recommend anyone that’s serious about synths or production In General and can afford it, this is the move. 

Otherwise, I’d go quality over quantity. Get a knobby analog synth that’s easy to make sounds quickly. You’ll have more fun if you’re used to more tactile instruments.

Having a digital synth with a bunch of menus that’s “more powerful” (3+ oscillators, several LFO’s, tons of polyphony) isn’t any fun when you can’t change the sounds quickly,easily, or intuitively. 

Korg MS20 was the first synth I fell in love with. Felt like playing guitar or something. Like an actual instrument.

Prophet 6 and OB-6 are incredible. If I had to pick one for myself it would be the OB-6. But the prophet is super versatile and usable in any style more so than the OB6.

I’d take an analog mono synth with knob per function over a powerful digital synth with menus

author: Zack Hames
content: The Korg logue is the shit though for bang for your buck. Knobby, affordable, analog.

author: bobby k
content: Let me preface by saying nothing tangible has got me feeling down or discouraged. In fact I think I'm in the best season of my life so far and it feels like everything is going right (aside: aren't you more likely to self sabotage when things are good than when they are bad?) to zoom out a little bit, i already know the answer. I'm doing too much at once, spreading myself thin beyond enjoyment. in the grit of a transition and it's clear where I'm going but I have no frame of reference for the timeline. A few years ago, I was mid-20s, in a band on a major, had roommates & cheap rent, and a chess app addiction. i was still a "professional" but things were extremely simple. in short, left the band, spent a few years mixing much more than producing, and now am swinging back that way. I'm about to turn 30, I have a mortgage, a (semi) dependent, my first real studio, an intern to set an example for, 5ish mixing clients at any moment, producing for 3 artists and co-prod/consulting on 2 other projects, playing occasionally in any of 4 different bands, and producing/recording some live performances (as well as starting a YT channel in this lane). In my experience at least, it really seems like something shifted at the top of this year, and I hate to say it but part of the fault is TikTok (is the rest of the fault mine?). Everything is urgent to everyone and nothing informs each other or oscillates together. It feels like a clock is constantly going "tick, tock, tick, tock" and the anxiety I once had over money is shifted completely towards my time management. Every time I look away from my phone I have 30 new texts. I think I'm crushing it in my professional demands but I don't know that I'm being the person I want to be for my friends, family and partner. I don't know that I'm setting a good example to this intern. I don't know that I'm there to take care of myself all the way.
